newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul to expand overseas borrowings to support won.
newsitem.headline: Seoul to expand overseas borrowings to support won.

text.p: South Korea's state banks will seek to expand overseas borrowings as part of government efforts to support the local currency, the finance ministry said on Monday.
As part of steps to encourage the inflow of foreign funds, the ministry was also considering speeding up the expansion of the foreign stock ownership limit, it said.
The government has said that the ceiling on foreign ownership will be raised in 1997 from 20 percent to 23 percent of a listed company.
"We will consider the expansion at en early date and in addition to the plan," the statement said.
The ministry, citing a large current account deficit that pressured the local currency, said the government would encourage locally-based firms to seek overseas loans.
"We plan to promote expansion of overseas borrowings by banks such as Korea Development Bank and Korea Export and Import Bank," the statement said. Both banks are run by the state.
The ministry said foreign manufacturers in South Korea would be allowed to freely borrow abroad if the money was to be used for operating expenses.
The won's value has fallen about six percent against the dollar since the beginning of this year. The won ended Friday at 897.50 to the dollar after touching a record low of 899.30 during the day.

The current account deficit rose to $2.45 billion in February from $1.97 billion a year before, according to Bank of Korea (central bank) figures. The deficit for 1996 was $23.72 billion against $10.06 billion in 1995. The government said it wanted to reduce the deficit to $18 billion this year.
The ministry earlier this month repealed ceilings on local banks' overseas borrowings and lifted the limit on equity-linked bond issues abroad by local companies.
Some foreign exchange dealers forecast the dollar should test the 930 won level in May as dollar demand to pay imports was unlikely to weaken.
